fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Vector Space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 1.20
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field. A Vector Space over \mathbb {F} consists of a set V equipped with vector addition +\colon V\times V\to V and scalar multiplication \cdot \colon \mathbb {F}\times V\to V such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: Commutativity: for all u,v\in V, we have u+v=v+u
Associativity: for all u,v,w\in V, we have (u+v)+w=u+(v+w)
Additive identity: there exists a \vec {0}\in V such that for all v\in V we have v+\vec {0}=v
Additive inverse: for each v\in V there exists a w\in V such that v+w=\vec {0}
Associativity of scalar multiplication: for all v\in V and a,b\in \mathbb {F}, we have (ab)v=a(bv)
Multiplicative identity: The multiplicative unital element 1\in \mathbb {F} is such that for all v\in V we have 1v=v
Distributivity: for all a,b\in \mathbb {F} and u,v\in V we have a(u+v)=au+av and (a+b)v=av+bv

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Compare this to the definition of a Real vector space from elementary linear algebra. When \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {R}, we call V a real vector space. When \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {C}, we call V a Complex Vector Space.

fr:title.text: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: https://www.math.ucdavis.edu/~anne/linear_algebra/mat67_course_notes.pdf

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear Algebra Done Right
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: https://linear.axler.net/

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Field is traditionally defined as a set F with two binary operators, addition (denoted +) and multiplication (denoted \cdot ), satisfying the field axioms:

fr:ol.fr:li: Associativity of addition: for all x,y,z\in F, (x+y)+z=x+(y+z)
Commutativity of addition: for all x,y\in F, x+y=y+x
Additive identity: there exists a 0\in F such that for all x\in F we have 0+x=x and x+0=x
Additive inverses: for each x\in F there is a unique y\in F such that x+y=0 and y+x=0; in this case, we usually denote y as (-x)
Associativity of multiplication: for all x,y,z\in F, (x\cdot y)\cdot z=x\cdot (y\cdot z)
Commutativity of multiplication: for all x,y\in F, x\cdot y=y\cdot x
Multiplicative identity: there exists a 1\in F such that for all x\in F we have 1\cdot x=x and x\cdot 1=x
Multiplicative inverses: for each x\in F which is nonzero x\neq 0 there is a unique y\in F such that x\cdot y=1 and y\cdot x=1; usually we denote y as x^{-1}
Distributivity of multiplication over addition: for all x,y,z\in F, we have x\cdot (y+z)=(x\cdot y)+(x\cdot z) and (x+y)\cdot z=(x\cdot z)+(x\cdot y)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note that some of these are redundant.
Also note: fields are usually written in blackboard bold, and the generic field is either \mathbb {F} or \Bbbk (since the German word for field is "Körper").

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Vector Space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 1.20
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field. A Vector Space over \mathbb {F} consists of a set V equipped with vector addition +\colon V\times V\to V and scalar multiplication \cdot \colon \mathbb {F}\times V\to V such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: Commutativity: for all u,v\in V, we have u+v=v+u
Associativity: for all u,v,w\in V, we have (u+v)+w=u+(v+w)
Additive identity: there exists a \vec {0}\in V such that for all v\in V we have v+\vec {0}=v
Additive inverse: for each v\in V there exists a w\in V such that v+w=\vec {0}
Associativity of scalar multiplication: for all v\in V and a,b\in \mathbb {F}, we have (ab)v=a(bv)
Multiplicative identity: The multiplicative unital element 1\in \mathbb {F} is such that for all v\in V we have 1v=v
Distributivity: for all a,b\in \mathbb {F} and u,v\in V we have a(u+v)=au+av and (a+b)v=av+bv

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Compare this to the definition of a Real vector space from elementary linear algebra. When \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {R}, we call V a real vector space. When \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {C}, we call V a Complex Vector Space.

fr:title.text: Finite tuples over a field form a vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finite tuples over a field form a vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Consider \mathbb {F}^{n} the set of all n-tuples with values in \mathbb {F}. This is a vector space with addition and multiplication defined by (u_{1},…,u_{n})+(v_{1},…,v_{n})=(u_{1}+v_{1},…,u_{n}+v_{n}) a(u_{1},…,u_{n})=(au_{1},…,au_{n}) Then this really is a vector space.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Vector space of sequences
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Example 1.23
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field. Then \mathbb {F}^{\infty } is the set of all sequences over \mathbb {F}. Then vector addition defined componentwise (u_{k})+(v_{k})=(u_{k}+v_{k}) and scalar multiplication defined componentwise a(u_{n})=(au_{n}) give us a vector space.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Polynomials form a vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Example 1.23
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F}[z] be the set of all polynomial with coefficients in \mathbb {F} and in unknown z. Then defining (p+q)(z)=p(z)+q(z) and (ap)(z)=ap(z) for any a\in \mathbb {F} and p,q\in \mathbb {F}[z] forms vector addition and scalar multiplication.

fr:title.text: Field-valued functions form a vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field-valued functions form a vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Example 1.25
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let D\neq \emptyset be any set. Let \mathbb {F} be a field. Then the Set of all functions \mathbb {F}^{D} forms a vector space. Vector addition of f,g\in \mathbb {F}^{D} is given by (f+g)(x)=f(x)+g(x) for any x\in D, and scalar multiplication is given by (af)(x)=af(x) for any a\in \mathbb {F}.

There are various related vector spaces of interest to Mathematicians. For example, when \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {R} and D\subseteq \mathbb {R}, the set of all continuous real-valued functions on D forms a subspace of \mathbb {R}^{D}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Zero vector is unique
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.26
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Then the additive identity \vec {0}\in V is unique.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Additive inverse is unique
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.27
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. For each v\in V, there is a unique additive inverse of v in V.
Suppose w and w' are additive inverses of v. Then w=w+0=w+(v+w')=(w+v)+w'=0+w'=w' which gives us w=w' as desired.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Additive inverse and vector subtraction
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Notation 1.28

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. We denote by -v the additive inverse of v\in V.
Similarly, for any v,w\in V, we denote by v-w the expression v+(-w).

fr:title.text: Scalar multiplication by zero gives zero vector

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Scalar multiplication by zero gives zero vector
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.30
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let v\in V and 0_{F}\in \mathbb {F}. Then 0_{F}v=\vec {0}.
We see by distributivity, 0_{F}v=(0_{F}+0_{F})v=0_{F}v+0_{F}v, and then subtracting 0_{F}v from both sides yields \vec {0}=0_{F}v-0_{F}v=(0_{F}v+0_{F}v)-0_{F}v=0_{F}v as desired.

fr:title.text: Scalar multiples of zero vector are the zero vector

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Scalar multiples of zero vector are the zero vector
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.31
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let \vec {0}\in V and a\in \mathbb {F}. Then a\vec {0}=\vec {0}.
We see a\vec {0}=a(\vec {0}+\vec {0})=a\vec {0}+a\vec {0}, then adding the additive inverse of a\vec {0} to both sides yields the result.

fr:title.text: Negating a vector by multiplying by minus one

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Negating a vector by multiplying by minus one
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.32
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let v\in V. Then (-1)v=-v.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 1.33
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.3.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let U\subseteq V be a subset. Then we call U a Subspace of V if U is a vector space over \mathbb {F} under the same operations that make V a vector space over \mathbb {F}.
In particular, V is always a subspace of itself.
Compare this to Subspace of a real vector space from elementary linear algebra.

fr:title.text: Criteria for subset to be a subspace

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for subset to be a subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.34
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 4.3.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let U\subseteq V be a subset. Then U is a subspace of V if the following conditions all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Additive identity: \vec {0}\in U
Closed under addition: for any u,v\in U, u+v\in U
Closed under scalar multiplication: for any a\in \mathbb {F} and u\in U, we have au\in U

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Trivial subspaces
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.3.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Then V is a subspace of V and also \{\vec {0}\} is a subspace of V. They are called the Trivial Subspaces of V.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sum of subspaces
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 1.36
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.4.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let U_{1},U_{2}\subseteq V be subspaces of V. We define the (Subspace) Sum of U_{1} and U_{2} to be the set U_{1}+U_{2}=\{u_{1}+u_{2}\mid u_{1}\in U_{1},u_{2}\in U_{2}\}.
More precisely, this is a subspace of V.
This can be extended to any finite number of subspaces of V.

fr:title.text: Sum of subspaces is smallest subspace containing the summands

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sum of subspaces is smallest subspace containing the summands
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.40

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U_{1},…,U_{m}\subseteq V be subspaces of a vector space V. Then U_{1}+…+U_{m} is the smallest subspace of V containing U_{1}, …, U_{n}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum of spaces
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 1.36
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.4.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U_{1},U_{2}\subseteq V be subspaces of a vector space. We call U_{1}+U_{2} the Direct Sum if each element of U_{1}+U_{2} can be written in only one way as a sum u_{1}+u_{2} where u_{1}\in U_{1} and u_{2}\in U_{2}.
In this case, we write U_{1}\oplus U_{2}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criterion for direct sum
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.45
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.4.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U_{1},U_{2}\subseteq V. Then U_{1}+U_{2} is a direct sum if and only if the only way we can write \vec {0}=u_{1}+u_{2} with u_{1}\in U_{1} and u_{2}\in U_{2} is for u_{1}=u_{2}=\vec {0}.

fr:title.text: Direct sum of two subspaces intersect in the zero subspace

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum of two subspaces intersect in the zero subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.46
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.4.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U_{1},U_{2}\subseteq V be subspaces. Then U_{1}+U_{2} is a direct sum if and only if U_{1}\cap U_{2}=\{\vec {0}\}.

fr:title.text: Direct sum as Cartesian product of underlying sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum as Cartesian product of underlying sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If we are just given any two vector spaces V_{1} and V_{2} over the same field \mathbb {F}, then we can still form the direct sum of these spaces. We just take V_{1}\oplus V_{2}=\{(v_{1},v_{2})\mid v_{1}\in V_{1},v_{2}\in V_{2}\} and the operations are defined componentwise.
This is known as the External Direct Sum, but it is not taught usually to undergraduates.

fr:title.text: Field extension is a vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field extension is a vector space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a Field extension over \mathbb {F}. Then \Bbbk is a Vector Space over \mathbb {F}.

fr:title.text: Modules over fields are synonymous with vector spaces

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Modules over fields are synonymous with vector spaces

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let M be either a Left Module over \mathbb {F} or a Right Module over \mathbb {F}. Then M is a Vector Space.
Moreover, any vector space over \mathbb {F} is automatically a module over \mathbb {F}.
Consequently, we treat "vector spaces over fields" as synonymous with "modules over fields".

We have implicitly used binary operators when discussion the algebra of matrices, Fields, Vector Spaces, and so on. Some concrete examples include Matrix Addition, Matrix Subtraction, and Matrix Multiplication.
Unary operators have been infrequently mentioned. For example, the Matrix Transpose is a unary operator on the set of matrices.
Tradition dictates we explicitly formalize the notions of binary and unary operators.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Binary operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set. A Binary Operator (or, more archaically, Law of Composition) is a function \mu \colon X\times X\to X which is various denoted using infixed notation a\star b or a\cdot b or ab (or, if commutative, a+b) for any a,b\in X.

fr:title.text: Function composition is a binary operator on the set of all functions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Function composition is a binary operator on the set of all functions

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a set. Then X=\mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits (A,A) the Set of all functions from A to A has a binary operator, namely Composition of functions.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Associative binary operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator on X. We say \mu is Associative if \forall a,b,c\in X\ldotp \mu (a,\mu (b,c))=\mu (\mu (a,b),c)
Examples of associative binary operators we have already seen in Mathematics:

fr:ul.fr:li: If A is a set and X=\mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits (A,A) is the Set of all functions from A to itself, we know Function composition is a binary operator on the set of all functions. It turns out that Composing functions is associative.
If \mathbb {F} is a Field, then both addition and multiplication is associative.
Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then the set of n\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {F} has Matrix Multiplication is Associative.

fr:mainmatter.fr:li: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then the set of n\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {F} can be equipped with the Commutator which is a binary operator denoted [A,B]=AB-BA for any n\times n matrices A and B over \mathbb {F}. The commutator is not associative, i.e., in general we have [A, [B, C]] \neq [[A,B],C] but it satisfies a variant called the Jacobi Identity: [A, [B, C]] + [B, [C, A]] + [C, [A, B]] = 0 for any n\times n matrices A, B, and C.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Commutative binary operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator on X. We say \mu is Commutative if \forall a,b\in X\ldotp \mu (a,b)=\mu (b,a)
Examples of commutative binary operators we have already seen in Mathematics:

fr:ul.fr:li: If \mathbb {F} is a Field, then both addition and multiplication is commutative.
Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then the set of n\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {F}, we see Matrix Addition is Commutative.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Some non-examples:

fr:ul.fr:li: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then the set of n\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {F}, we see Matrix Multiplication is not commutative.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity element
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator on X. Let e\in X be an element. We say e is a Unit (or identity element) for \mu if \forall a\in X\ldotp \mu (a,e)=a\land \mu (e,a)=a.

fr:title.text: Examples of identity element for a binary operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Examples of identity element for a binary operator

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Examples of identity elements for binary operators we have already seen in Mathematics:

fr:ul.fr:li: If A is a set and X=\mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits (A,A) is the Set of all functions from A to itself, we know Function composition is a binary operator on the set of all functions. It turns out that the Identity function is the identity element for the Composition of functions.
If \mathbb {F} is a Field, then its 0 acts as an identity element for addition and 1 acts as an identity element for multiplication.

Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then the set of n\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {F} we see that Multiplying by Identity Matrix acts like an identity element for matrix multiplication; and also Matrix Addition with Zero Matrix has the zero matrix act like the identity element for matrix addition.

fr:title.text: Commutator of matrices has no identity element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Commutator of matrices has no identity element

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Commutator of matrices over a Field \mathbb {F} (or a suitable ring). It turns out, the commutator has no identity element. If it had one, say \mathbf {E}, then for any matrix \mathbf {A} we would have [\mathbf {E},\mathbf {A}]=\mathbf {A} and by anticommutativity of the commutator [\mathbf {A},\mathbf {E}]=-\mathbf {A}. But then we find the Jacobi Identity fails to hold: [\mathbf {E},[\mathbf {B},\mathbf {C}]] + [\mathbf {B}, [\mathbf {C}, \mathbf {E}]] + [\mathbf {C}, [\mathbf {E}, \mathbf {B}]] = [\mathbf {C},\mathbf {B}]\neq 0.

fr:title.text: Identity element is at most unique

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity element is at most unique

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator on X. Then there exists at most 1 Identity element for \mu in X.
If e_{1}\in A and e_{2}\in A are two possible identity elements, then e_{1}=\mu (e_{1},e_{2})=e_{2}.

fr:title.text: Inverse of an element with respect to a binary operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inverse of an element with respect to a binary operator

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a set equipped with a Binary operator \mu with an identity element e\in A, let a\in A. A (Two-Sided) Inverse of a is an element b\in A such that \mu (a,b)=\mu (b,a)=e.

(1) If \mu is an Associative binary operator, then we can just speak of "inverses" of elements without the "two-sided" prefix. This is because the Inverse with respect to an associative binary operator is unique
(2) If there are multiple binary operators on A, then we should specify that b is an inverse of a with respect to \mu .

fr:title.text: Inverse with respect to an associative binary operator is unique

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inverse with respect to an associative binary operator is unique

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a set, let \mu be an Associative binary operator on A. Let e\in A be the Identity element for \mu . For any element a\in A, there is at most 1 inverse for a with respect to \mu .

fr:title.text: General Linear group of a vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: General Linear group of a vector space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field. Let V be a Vector Space over \mathbb {F}. We define the General Linear Group on V to be the group \mathop {\textrm {GL}}\nolimits (V) consisting of all invertible linear maps from V to itself, equipped with composition and the identity linear transformation as the identity element.

When we pick an ordered basis B for V and write matrix M(g) relative to B for each linear transformation g\in \mathop {\textrm {GL}}\nolimits (V), then we recover the General Linear Group of matrices over \mathbb {F}.

This is loosely following the material covered in the Math 5 series at California Institute of Technology (based on Dummit and Foote's Abstract Algebra) or the Math 150 series at University of California, Davis (based on Artin's Algebra).
We have already seen a number of different "species" of Mathematical Gadgets, like:

It turns out, all the information which was really interesting was encoded in the "structure-preserving transformations" between them. (That was the bulk of our time spent studying Elementary linear algebra and Intermediate linear algebra, after all!)
We can form an abstraction describing this situation where we have a [gadget] and [transformations] between them: this is category theory.

fr:title.text: Traditional way of teaching abstract algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Traditional way of teaching abstract algebra

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The traditional way we teach undergraduates is by introducing several types of gadgets in abstract algebra in the following order:

fr:ol.fr:li: Initially, there's some discussion of set theory sufficient for developing algebra. This is "time honored tradition" starting with van der Waerden's book.

When the structure-preserving transformations leave something invariant (e.g., Invariant subspaces in linear algebra), composing such transformations also leaves the thing invariant. This is the guiding intuition of what a "symmetry" is, and the "collection of symmetries" is precisely what a "group" is (originally, they were a "group of symmetries" or a symmetry group).

fr:li.fr:p: (a) But we also saw how, e.g., square matrices have a neat algebraic structure with matrix addition and matrix multiplication. They act like a "number system". This is precisely what is studied with number ring (or just a Ring). A sufficiently nice ring is a Field.
(b) We can generalize linear algebra to describe "vector spaces over arbitrary rings", and these are modules.

fr:ol.fr:li: Galois theory is offered as the pinnacle of abstract algebra, connecting group theory to field theory. Honestly, I never understood the excitement behind Galois theory, since the beautiful parts of it are just the representation theory of groups (describing how "the same symmetries appearing in different situations").

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This is just the first 7 chapters of van der Waerden's Modern Algebra, Vol. I. Most textbooks have followed this manner of presentation: Dummit and Foote's Abstract Algebra covers this material in the first 14 chapters; Hungerford's Algebra does this in the first 6 chapters.

fr:title.text: Modern ways to teach abstract algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Modern ways to teach abstract algebra

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The more modern approaches to teaching abstract algebra incorporates some degree of category theory into the mix.

Aluffi's Algebra: Chapter 0 is perhaps the most bold attempt to reorganize abstract algebra around category theory entirely. Instead of ending at Galois theory, Aluffi concludes with homological algebra.
Some ideas from the traditional approach (like "groups with operators") turn out to be confused and muddled (which should be replaced with groups acting on other groups).

If I had to teach abstract algebra to undergraduates, I am torn between the traditional approaches (starting from van der Waerden's Moderne Algebra onwards) which I just outlined, and more modern adaptations which wrap everything in the framework of category theory. Aluffi's Algebra: Chapter Zero seemingly attempts a happy medium, and I am unhappy with it.

One fortunate aspect to Forester is that I'm not forced to choose one or the other. I can outline the "traditional" presentation of topics, and the "modern" presentation of topics, and allow the reader to pick which manner of presentation they wish to peruse.
When a Group has a commutative binary operator, we call it an Abelian group (or a Commutative group).
Typically, for Abelian groups, we write the binary operator as addition, and the identity element as 0.

I have grown to believe over the years that an Abelian group should be reserved for a generalization of a Vector Space if we just forget about scalar multiplication and the field. This is how most proof assistants handle it.
Commutative groups are groups which are, well, equipped with a Commutative binary operator.
When we define a Group (or Vector Space or...), we typically have a kind of "template" for the definition which looks like:

html:blockquote.fr:p: A Gadget consists of some stuff (sets or other gadgets like fields) equipped with some structure (functions, subsets, subset families like topologies, or specific elements) such that a bunch of properties (usually equations) hold.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: John Baez and James Dolan were the first to explore this template for definitions. See also Sections 2.4 and 3.1 of Baez and Shulman.

Model theorists typically describe this as a tuple (all the "stuff" and "structure" are crammed together into one tuple) which satisfy some axioms (the "properties"). While this is neat, it lacks some of the desired "inheritance" (like a Field really is an Abelian group with addition, extended with a multiplication operator and a "one" element). Computer Scientists would suggest using a "finite map" instead of a tuple.

There is also some tension between "Mathematical Practice" and what is desirable when formalizing concepts in a proof assistant. For example, we would often want to define a group as a group object internal to the category of sets, but that adds a lot of needless complications to formalizing this in a proof assistant (where we would want as Spartan a structure as possible).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Field is traditionally defined as a set F with two binary operators, addition (denoted +) and multiplication (denoted \cdot ), satisfying the field axioms:

fr:ol.fr:li: Associativity of addition: for all x,y,z\in F, (x+y)+z=x+(y+z)
Commutativity of addition: for all x,y\in F, x+y=y+x
Additive identity: there exists a 0\in F such that for all x\in F we have 0+x=x and x+0=x
Additive inverses: for each x\in F there is a unique y\in F such that x+y=0 and y+x=0; in this case, we usually denote y as (-x)
Associativity of multiplication: for all x,y,z\in F, (x\cdot y)\cdot z=x\cdot (y\cdot z)
Commutativity of multiplication: for all x,y\in F, x\cdot y=y\cdot x
Multiplicative identity: there exists a 1\in F such that for all x\in F we have 1\cdot x=x and x\cdot 1=x
Multiplicative inverses: for each x\in F which is nonzero x\neq 0 there is a unique y\in F such that x\cdot y=1 and y\cdot x=1; usually we denote y as x^{-1}
Distributivity of multiplication over addition: for all x,y,z\in F, we have x\cdot (y+z)=(x\cdot y)+(x\cdot z) and (x+y)\cdot z=(x\cdot z)+(x\cdot y)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note that some of these are redundant.
Also note: fields are usually written in blackboard bold, and the generic field is either \mathbb {F} or \Bbbk (since the German word for field is "Körper").
A Real Vector Space consists of a set V with two binary operators, scalar multiplication \odot \colon \mathbb {R}\times V\to V and vector addition \oplus \colon V\times V\to V, such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: Closure of \oplus : for any u,v\in V, we have u\oplus v\in V;
Commutativity of \oplus : for any u,v\in V, we have u\oplus v=v\oplus u;
Associativity of \oplus : for any u,v,w\in V, we have (u\oplus v)\oplus w=u\oplus (v\oplus W);
Unit of \oplus : there exists a \vec {0}\in V such that for all u\in V we have \vec {0}+u=u and also u+\vec {0}=u;
Existence of negation: for each u\in V, there exists a -u\in V such that u\oplus -u=\vec {0};
Closure of \odot : for any real number c\in \mathbb {R} and for any u\in V, we have c\odot u\in V;
Left distributivity of \odot over \oplus : for any c\in \mathbb {R} and u,v\in V, we have c\odot (u\oplus v)=(c\odot u)\oplus (c\odot v);
Right distributivity of \odot over \oplus : for any c,d\in \mathbb {R} and u,v\in V, we have (c+d)\odot u=(c\odot u)\oplus (d\odot u);
Unit of \odot : for any u\in V, 1\odot u=u

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We call elements of V Vectors of V.

Notation varies book to book, especially with introductory linear algebra. Later on in Mathematics (and physics) we just write u+v for vector addition and c\cdot u or cu for scalar multiplication. But since we are trying to be explicit and clear, we demarcate vector addition and scalar multiplication with separate notation from field operations.
We could replace the real numbers \mathbb {R} with the complex numbers \mathbb {C} to define a notion of a complex vector space, nothing changes except where the scalars live.
